channel.title: Bloomberg Markets

item.title: Chanos and Saylor Clash in a Wall Street War of Words
item.description: The two investors have quarreled over what Chanos sees as the “big short.”
item.dc:creator: Lynn Thomasson, Subrat Patnaik

media:content.media:description: Jim Chanos, founder and president of Chanos & Company LP, during a Bloomberg Television interview in New York, US, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. Chanos discussed the state of markets and his concerns about the lack of oversight in the crypto market. Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg

item.title: Serbia Unexpectedly Holds Rates as Caution Tops Growth Pace
item.description: Serbia’s central bank unexpectedly kept borrowing costs unchanged for a ninth month, sticking to a cautious policy approach even as inflation eases and economic growth slows.
item.dc:creator: Misha Savic

media:content.media:description: The Serbian Central Bank headquarters in Belgrade, Serbia, on Saturday, May 10, 2025. Serbia President Aleksandar Vucic attended events in Russia’s capital marking the 80th anniversary of victory in World War II and is expected to negotiate a new gas contract with Vladimir Putin. Photographer: Oliver Bunic/Bloomberg

item.title: Dollar Hits Fresh 2025 Low as US Tariff Concerns Pick Up Again
item.description: The dollar extended its decline as worries over US tariffs increased after President Donald Trump said he would notify trading partners soon of unilateral levies.
item.dc:creator: David Finnerty, Vassilis Karamanis

item.title: Stocks, Dollar Drop as Trade Jitters Stir Risk-Off: Markets Wrap
item.description: Equities and the dollar retreated as dialed-up trade tensions and geopolitical unease set a broader risk-off tone across markets.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren, Julien Ponthus

media:content.media:description: DoubleLine Group CEO Jeffrey Gundlach talks about the price of gold, fixed income, private credit, President Donald Trump's tax bill, Federal Reserve monetary policy and artificial intelligence with Lisa Abramowicz at the Bloomberg Global Credit Forum in Los Angeles.

item.title: ECB’s Schnabel Says Rate-Cutting Campaign Is Coming to an End
item.description: The European Central Bank’s interest-rate cutting campaign may soon be over, with inflation and the economy both on track, Executive Board member Isabel Schnabel said.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Mark Schroers

item.title: Nordea Announces Third €250 Million Buyback Program This Year
item.description: Nordea Bank Abp has received approval from the European Central Bank for a new €250 million ($289 million) share buyback program, the third of its kind so far this year.
item.dc:creator: Evelina Youcefi

media:content.media:description: The Nordea Bank Abp headquarters in Stockholm. Photographer: Mikael Sjoberg/Bloomberg

item.title: AGI CEO Says US Stocks Overpriced
item.description: European equities are “quite cheap” on a price-earnings basis, while US stocks have been overpriced, Allianz Global Investors CEO Tobias Pross tells Bloomberg's Sonali Basak. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: ECB Is in Good Position to Withstand Future Shocks, Lagarde Says
item.description: President Christine Lagarde reiterated that the European Central Bank is well placed to handle any abrupt shifts in the economy.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

item.title: Hong Kong's Riches Revealed
item.description: "Bloomberg's Richard Frost, Mary Hui and Filipe Pacheco introduce Sonali Basak to Hong Kong. " (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Israel, Gulf Stocks Drop as Middle East Tensions Rise Again
item.description: Stock markets across the Middle East fell on Thursday, with Israel’s benchmark index the worst-performer globally as traders responded to heightened tensions in the region.
item.dc:creator: Tugce Ozsoy

item.title: China a Hedge Against Trump Says Ex Canada Fin Min
item.description: Canada should bolster ties with China to hedge against uncertainty from US President Donald Trump’s approach to bilateral relations, according to former Canadian Finance Minister Bill Morneau. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nasdaq Offers Huge Opportunity
item.description: Tom Digby, Head of ETF Business Development & Capital Markets, Asia Pacific, Invesco QQQ tells Bloomberg's Rebecca Sin how Nasdaq listed companies offer great returns in the medium to long term. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Yields on 30-Year Bonds to Fall in Long Term: AllianzGI
item.description: Virginie Maisonneuve of Allianz Global Investors comments on the outlook for 30-year Treasury bond yields which peaked in May and have lingered near 5% since. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Gold Steadies as Traders Weigh Middle East Tensions and Tariffs
item.description: Gold steadied, after rising on escalating tensions in the Middle East, while President Donald Trump ratcheted up trade uncertainty with remarks that he intends to impose unilateral tariffs on dozens of US trading within two weeks.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie, Jack Ryan

media:content.media:description: Gold bars at the Italpreziosi SpA precious metals refinery plant arranged in Arezzo, Italy, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Gold fell, snapping a two-day advance, as signs of progress on US-China trade talks curbed demand for havens even as military hostilities between India and Pakistan escalated. Photographer: Alessia Pierdomenico/Bloomberg

item.title: Clearlake’s Feliciano Sees Slower Private Equity Growth Over Next Decade
item.description: Clearlake Capital Group co-founder José Feliciano explains why he expects slower growth in private equity over the next decade and why private credit is “well positioned” for retail investors. He speaks with Dani Burger at Bloomberg’s Global Credit Forum in Los Angeles (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Sizzling Rally in US Stocks Leaves Them Pricey Compared to Bonds
item.description: Traders who hung on during this year’s tariff-fueled rollercoaster ride in stocks are facing a conundrum: Bonds may offer more attractive returns in coming years, according to one widely tracked measure.
item.dc:creator: Jess Menton

item.title: Oil Slips as Traders Take Stock of Tensions in the Middle East
item.description: Oil retreated from its surge over Middle East tensions as traders weigh the latest developments in the region against a risk-off mood triggered by renewed tariff threats from Washington.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Sarah Chen

item.title: Egypt Makes LNG Supply Deals With Aramco, Trafigura and Shell
item.description: Egypt agreed to buy liquefied natural gas cargoes for as many as two years from suppliers including Saudi Aramco, Trafigura Group and Vitol Group, putting the country on course to be a long-term importer as local production slows.
item.dc:creator: Salma El Wardany, Stephen Stapczynski, Anna Shiryaevskaya

media:content.media:description: The Cairo West power plant in Egypt.

item.title: Oil Edges Lower as Traders Take Stock of Mideast Tension
item.description: Oil prices edged lower — after jumping more than 4% on Wednesday — as traders tracked tensions in the Middle East and the latest moves in US trade policy. Bloomberg’s Anthony DiPaola reports.

item.title: Taiwan Eases Rules to Help Insurers Cope With Currency Surge
item.description: Taiwan regulators have moved to help the island’s insurers deal with the impact of a recent surge in the local currency, which had left them with massive paper losses on their foreign holdings.
item.dc:creator: Betty Hou

media:content.media:description: Taiwanese one thousand dollar banknotes Photographer: An Rong Xu/Bloomberg

item.title: Why Rare Earths Are China’s Trump Card in Trade War With US
item.description: Rare earths are among the most critical raw materials on the planet, deeply embedded in the technologies that underpin modern life. Yet few people have heard of them or know what they do.
item.dc:creator: Joe Deaux

media:content.media:description: Annealed neodymium iron boron magnets sit in a barrel prior to being crushed into powder.

item.title: Deutsche Bank Says Traders Overcame ‘Rough Start’ to Quarter
item.description: Deutsche Bank AG’s fixed income and currency traders overcame a choppy start to the second quarter and should deliver a better result than a year earlier, according to Chief Executive Officer Christian Sewing.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Comfort

item.title: China Gets First Private Builder Dollar Bond Offering Since 2023
item.description: Seazen Group Ltd., one of the few major private-sector Chinese developers yet to default, marketed a dollar bond that would be the first of its kind in more than two years.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Cai, Ameya Karve, Qingqi She, Emma Dong

item.title: Nuclear Startup Oklo to Raise $400 Million in Share Offering
item.description: Oklo Inc., a nuclear energy startup developing small reactors, is seeking to raise as much as $400 million in a secondary share offering.
item.dc:creator: Will Wade

item.title: Horizons Middle East & Africa 06/12/2025
item.description: Horizons Middle East & Africa is your daily spotlight on one of the world's fastest-growing regions. Live from Dubai, we bring you the latest global markets and analysis, plus news-making interviews, with a special focus on MEA. All that and more, as you head to the office in the Gulf, pause for lunch in Hong Kong, or start your day in London or Johannesburg. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Czech Leader Calls on Trump to Give Europe Time to Rearm
item.description: Czech President, Petr Pavel, on the Europe's security and securing peace in Ukraine. He said European nations can't secure peace without American help, but the continent needs more time and realistic goals. He speaks with Bloomberg's Kriti Gupta in Prague. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Norway Wealth Fund Puts TD Bank Under Observation for Four Years
item.description: Norway’s $1.9 trillion sovereign wealth fund put Toronto-Dominion Bank under observation for four years as the Canadian lender works to improve controls and culture, following a historic money laundering settlement.
item.dc:creator: Evelina Youcefi

media:content.media:description: A Toronto-Dominion bank building in Toronto.

item.title: US Long-Dated Debt Faces Crucial Test in $22 Billion Auction
item.description: After weeks of hand-wringing around demand for long-term US debt, all eyes are on Thursday’s 30-year Treasury auction for a fresh read on whether spiraling deficits are causing investors to shun the maturity.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie

media:content.media:description: The United States Department of the Treasury building in Washington DC.

item.title: Ant International Seeks Stablecoin Permits in Hong Kong, Singapore
item.description: Jack Ma-backed Ant Group Co.’s international unit is planning to apply for stablecoin licenses in Singapore and Hong Kong, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Lulu Yilun Chen

media:content.media:description: Attendees at the Ant Group booth at the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, July 6, 2023. The conference runs through July 8. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: China-Operated Ship Transports US Ethane to India for First Time
item.description: A Chinese-operated ship that had exclusively transported US ethane to the Asian nation is now en route to India with a cargo for the first time, following trade tensions between the world’s two biggest economies.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Lua, Sarah Chen, Serene Cheong

media:content.media:description: The STL Qianjiang is signaling Dahej on India’s west coast.
